left.name: Tucute
left.description: Those with higher Tucute scores believe that dysphoria is unnecessary to identify as transgender. They tend to believe in a “trans umbrella” that includes “non-dysphoric trans people”, and tend to support MOGAI labels. Extreme tucutes may also support transrace, transabled, transage, or minor-attracted people.

right.name: Transmed
right.description: Those with higher Transmed scores believe that transgender identity necessitates gender dysphoria. They support preventing anyone from saying they’re trans with no standards, expanding trans healthcare capabilities to do so, and tend to dismiss MOGAI labels as transphobic nonsense. Extreme transmedicalists may also disbelieve in nonbinary gender identity.

left.name: Left
left.description: Those with higher Left scores are politically left-leaning. They tend to support higher social equality and equal civil rights and opportunity for all, and tend to oppose neoliberal capitalism, among other forms of oppression.

right.name: Right
right.description: Those with higher Right scores are politically right-leaning. They tend to favor economic deregulation, patriotism, and possibly other conservative principles, and tend to believe in certain forms of natural hierarchy in society.

left.name: Vocalized
left.description: Those with higher Vocalized scores are outspoken trans advocates. They are often openly trans and tend to support large trans public figures in real life or online, and tend to view the discussion of trans-related issues as an open, active affair in which all trans people must participate. Those with extreme scores may be accused of making their gender their entire personality.

right.name: Low Profile
right.description: Those with higher Low Profile scores either withdraw from mainstream trans advocacy. They are less likely to be openly trans, focus more on trans people being able to pass and live a happy life over being forced to out themselves to argue about trans people, and tend to favor one-on-one conversation over public discourse. Those with extreme scores may favor a lowering of the general visibility of trans people.

left.name: Liberation
left.description: Those with higher Liberation scores seek to make the trans community stand out from cis-normative society. They tend to see “transgender” as a label to flaunt and be proud of, conflate sex, gender identity, and gender expression, and oppose trans people seeking to pass as their true gender, as with many social norms.

right.name: Assimilation
right.description: Those with higher Assimilation scores do not see cisnormative society as something trans people must change to live their best life, or be skeptic of radical cisphobic elements in the mainstream trans liberation movement. They recognize the difference between sex, gender identity, and gender expression. They tend to favor adherence to social norms, both aesthetically and behaviorally.

left.name: Abstract
left.description: Those with higher Abstract scores believe that being trans is an abstract experience that occurs first and foremost in the mind. They tend to enjoy discussing theories related to the trans experience, be more idealistic about its possibilities, and see it as an intellectual field to be expanded upon.

right.name: Concrete
right.description: Those with higher Concrete scores believe that being trans is a concrete experience that encompasses tangible steps and observable outcomes. They tend to believe in a realistic or even pessimistic outlook of the trans experience, and tend to be less concerned with the theoretical and idealistic.

left.name: Zoomer
left.description: Those with higher Zoomer scores have a cultural mindset more aligned with stereotypical Generation Z transgender culture. They tend to be well-versed in trans-related tropes, jokes, and memes online, and tend to value the internet as a hub of the trans community.

right.name: Boomer
right.description: Those with higher Boomer scores have a cultural mindset more out of touch with stereotypical Generation Z transgender culture. They tend to be less well-versed in the happening and trends of the online trans community, and at times, skeptical of modern transgender culture.
